description: The Aga Khan Museum provides visitors with a window into the artistic, intellectual, and scientific contributions of Muslim civilizations to world heritage.

reviews.title: It was informative and good to know the Islamic history
text: The Aga Khan Museum in Toronto is an architectural marvel, set within a beautifully designed campus that includes a serene reflection pool and impressive international-quality structures.

The galleries are thoughtfully laid out and easy to navigate, featuring a diverse array of Islamic art. The collection spans a vast geographical range, from the Middle East to India and beyond, and includes artifacts from different historical periods. Visitors can explore ancient manuscripts, intricate ceramics, and beautifully crafted textiles, all of which highlight the rich heritage of Islamic art.

One of the most impressive aspects of the museum is its wide historical and topical range. The exhibits cover everything from classical pieces to contemporary works, offering a comprehensive view of Islamic artistic traditions. Several contemporary pieces stand out for their innovative interpretations and thought-provoking themes.

Additionally, the museum offers interactive displays and multimedia presentations that enhance the visitor experience, making the art more accessible and engaging. The Aga Khan Museum also hosts a variety of cultural events, performances, and educational programs that further enrich the visitor experience.

The museum staff were exceptionally kind and welcoming, enhancing our visit with their warmth and professionalism. Several knowledgeable docents provided fascinating insights into the exhibits, enriching our understanding of the art and its cultural significance.

Overall, the Aga Khan Museum is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in the rich tapestry of Islamic art and culture. Its blend of beautiful architecture, diverse collections, and educational offerings make it a standout cultural institution in Toronto.

reviews.title: Love this Place

The food is great in their cafe and restaurant. The gift shop has great items. The location is perfect. The surrounding park is beautiful and always a great place for taking pics. I will return.

reviews.title: Extraordinary architecture on beautiful campus.
text: The campus of the museum is beautifully designed with reflection pool and international-quality architecture. We visited on a day when only the first floor of the museum was open. The staff were exceptionally kind and open; several docents offered us interesting insights to the work. The galleries are easily navigated, containing a wide variety of Islamic art, from the Mideast to Indian and beyond. Wide historical and topical range with several very interesting contemporary works.

text: Dewan Resturant amazing food and Ambience.
Must try restaurant.
The Museum is beautiful and must visit.

reviews.title: Very enjoyable visit!
text: We visited this museum as we were visiting Toronto . Parking is $10 which you can pay as you pay entrance fees inside. It’s 15 dollars for a senior. The outside of the museum is oddly shaped and during spring, summer , and fall there are fountains and gardens in the front of it but unfortunately since it’s winter it was closed. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful..Now this museum introduces Islamic art throughout rare 1,200 objects assembled by its Highness the Aga Khan and Prince Saddrudin Aga Khan. What I enjoyed was seeing the different arts and objects collected throughout the years from different countries. The whole thing was very well explained which I appreciated. It took 1 1/2 hours to 2 hours to visit .

reviews.title: Good experience, not sure it was worth the price
text: My husband and I enjoyed the artwork on display. The history being portrayed within the museum is very biased in that all of the ways Islam has influenced the world through technological advances, art, culture, and religion would appear to remain pure without the influence of Greeco Roman societies, the Spanish, the Armenians, or any of the other peoples in those areas where Islam has spread to include Canadian culture. While we did not have an issue with the museum and understand the foundation is very pro-Islam, for anyone who would not find this acceptable, I cannot recommend going. The price of the tickets was a bit steep for the amount of time you can spend in the museum. We bought general admission and the whole three floors only took an hour for us to go through. We read every placard in each of the exhibitions. Also, I have lived in many of the nations where the artwork originated. One item of interest to me was the Astrolabe. I have never seen a physical one, so that was a highlight of the trip for us. We appreciate the pottery and learned how pottery could be used as a water filtration system. Again, it was an outstanding learning experience and might well be worth the admission if you have never been to the ancient world. However, for us, few items were unfamiliar.

reviews.title: Place to visit in Toronto
text: An amazing collection of art and information. Worth a few hours of your time. Off the beaten path but easy to get to.

reviews.title: Very Nice Museum
text: Wonderful museum with great staff.  If travelling by public transit, take the Metro to Pape (this is a temporary change) and catch bus 100A (departs every 10 minutes and stops in front of the museum)...a $4 admission discount is offered if you show your Presto Card.  The Diwan restaurant requires advance reservations but the separate small cafe is pretty good if you can't get in to Diwan.  Also worth a visit in the area is the Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre.

reviews.title: Interesting Visit
text: Interesting displays mostly from the Middle Eastern influence. Building itself could be slightly more aesthetically pleasing. Overall an okay experience.

reviews.title: Well curated small museum for Islamic art.
text: The museum is small in size and not over whelming so you can easily spend an afternoon browsing through the different artefacts.
They have interesting exhibits and immersive art objects that compel you to spend time looking at them.
They have put in touch less entry to the different rooms. I particularly enjoyed the travelling exhibit of refugees and carpets.
The grounds are beautiful as well with infinite pools. We happened to be here during a Indian bridal wear show and it looked lovely against the backdrop of the museum.
I have been here in the past for nuit blanche and enjoyed the dervish performance.

reviews.title: Open again
text: The Aga Khan Museum is relatively small, but it has a fine permanent collection of Islamic art and artifacts, and its special exhibitions are invariably all-considered and well-curated. The museum recently reopened, with additional features to keep visitors  safe from COVID-19 infection, including electronic devices that allow doors to be opened with the wave of a hand: a nice 1001-Nights touch! I particularly liked the special exhibition on "Sanctuary", which made the plight of several million displaced persons more real to those of us fortunate not to have to flee our home countries.

reviews.title: always a great visit
text: I've been to this museum several times and always found their exhibits to be incredibly well done and thoughtful. They often have live performances on as well.
Its not a very large museum, so an hour is enough time to see everything, though you could easily spend two if you stop and read everything.
I visited during covid and found that there was lots of space, all the doors had automated sensors and the museum was clearly taking all their precautions and rules seriously.

reviews.title: Unusual Museum
text: The history of Persia (Iran) unfolds in room after room of well-explained art and artifacts. Special exhibits and even performances and lectures take place in the auditorium.  There's also both a cafe and good sit-down restaurant here. A bit out-of-the-way but worth a stop.

reviews.title: Would definitely go again.
text: The exhibits were excellent.  I thoroughly enjoyed the experience.  Since only half the exhibits were open the cost was half price.  I would definitely go again to see the full exhibit.

reviews.title: Modern architecture with a classical touch
text: This museum highlights the path of Islam throughout history, yet incorporates other religions and cultures as well, including Judaism and Christianity. The space is welcoming and innovative and also a great venue for events outside of the museum's scheduled activities.

reviews.title: Excellent Museum
text: This was our second visit to this museum (first time was in 2016), and both times, we enjoyed it.
It is a small museum, but very interesting.
Particularly, the "Caravans of Gold" exhibit was engaging.
The only issue we found is the lack of light for reading the labels.

reviews.title: More Building than Exhibit.
text: Massive chunky building that I didn't find aesthetically pleasing.
And inside there was not enough displays for the size of the building.
Still, if you really want to look at Middle Eastern stuff then you will be happy.

reviews.title: Fascinating and beautiful
text: I arrived in time for the first tour of the main collection. And, luckily for me, I was the only person there. I had an excellent softly spoken , knowledgable and courteous guide. I loved the museum. I loved an alternative history to the western history I learned in school. I loved the beauty of the artifacts. I loved the beauty of the harmonious message and love if knowledge that the artifacts represented. Well worth the price of admission and tour.

reviews.title: Count on spending at least 1/2 day
text: Book to eat at the restaurant. Diwan on Open Table. You will NOT be disappointed. Hard to get to so drive there or figure out the new Eglinton Subway LRT link I think.  Spend time sitting outside looking at the magnificent fountains and architecture.  Stunning. Not to be missed.

reviews.title: Not much to see here...
text: That was my shortest museum tour ever. One big display room, one tiny one with ceramics and a small temporary display upstairs. No I am not affiliated with this culture nor a scholar of Arabic arts and therefore could not appreciate the details. Unless you answered yes to the above criteria save yourself the bother and visit the ROM instead.

reviews.title: Architectural masterpiece
text: We booked the museum tickets online for a Saturday between 10:00-11:00am. There was a special and they charged $10 each for adults instead of $20. The parking is $10. We paid on line but when we parked we didn’t have to put anything on the front dashboard. The lady at the front desk told us that they scan our E receipts on the second floor. There are only 2 floors and a basement. There is a gift shop, restaurant and cafe. The Islamic Centre is a 3 minute walk from Aga Khan. It’s free to visit but we didn’t go. They had a magician at 12:00 for the kids and it was under a tent. The art exhibits were interesting and there was details of each piece. Some of the rooms could have better lighting. It seemed a little dark. There was some musicians sitting on the floor playing instruments in a Middle Eastern style music. It’s a beautiful museum and it’s worth a visit.

reviews.title: Nice and tidy museum, but not much to see
text: There are exhibits on the first and second floors, but they are both essentially large rooms. Lots of interesting ancient artifacts to look at. The entire experience lasts under an hour at most.
Cheap admission (only $10, or free on Wednesday evenings), and parking is $10 for the entire day.

reviews.title: Beautiful museum
text: I really liked the Aga Khan musem! The building is beautiful and the collection is well laid out. It contains some interesting pieces like the oliphant from medieval Sicily, and overall it is very interesting.
The location is a bit out of the way, and depending on traffic it might take you a while to get there in a taxi.

reviews.title: Ok to spend 2 hrs
text: I am giving this museum an average score because there need to be control over the noise level and better lighting.
2 hrs would be more than enough to visit this museum. It is family oriented, hence all the screaming kids! Lots to learn about Islam.
Parking is poorly marked - we found the underground parking by fluke!
If you are in the area and need to kill time, I would recommend, but a special trip for this may not be justifiable.

reviews.title: Go
text: The only thing on the downside (for some) for the Aga Khan museum is that it's outside of the downtown core.  But get an uber and go. It's fascinating and has some outstanding exhibits. Easy to spend 2-3 hours there. And plan to have a meal – the restaurant is terrific.

reviews.title: Fascinating Collection
text: Beautiful space filled with medieval treasures to ponder and explore. A unique experience that everyone enjoyed! They also have a great lineup of events. Cons: A bit hard to get to via public transit.

reviews.title: A worthwhile visit
text: I came across this as I looked for a place to visit with a group of my intercultural studies students. This museum, focused as it was on Islamic cultures, was perfect. It was reasonably priced, in part because the top floor was closed as they prepared for a new exhibit. The main exhibit floor was very well presented and laid out, and organized according to region. A worthwhile visit.

reviews.title: Unique Museum
text: Aga Khan is among the museums which would give you a unique experience of getting to know the middle eastern Islamic culture in Toronto. There is a permanent collection on the ground floor which is devided into different regions of the Islamoc world in which unique features of architecture, calligraphy and culture are in display. There is also the second floor for the temporary exhibition which would be on for a fee months. The gardens around the museum are also interesting to explore.

reviews.title: Beautiful artifacts
text: A very nice museum with beautiful historical artifacts. An interesting and educational experience. I would recommend.

reviews.title: If you like mosaics and caligraphy, this is a great stop.
text: It was a neat experience. I haven't been to anything like that in North America. Lots of beautiful Arabic and Islamic art.

reviews.title: A beautiful space with well done displays
text: we went during a busy doors open Toronto visit. we were able to see live music and a lot of in depth displays about Muslim heritage.

reviews.title: Meh,
text: Attended a wedding here......meh...i dont see the great yadda yadda about it. I don't see the motive one would suggest to host here .

reviews.title: The Rumi exhibition is fascinating
text: Rumi was no more than a name to me before we saw the exhibition that was focussed on the life and work of this Sufi mystic and poet. The Aga Khan Museum specializes in exhibitions that expand our knowledge and appreciation of various aspects of Muslim civilization and culture, and this one is no exception. It runs all summer; I strongly recommend that you see it.

reviews.title: Wonderful guided tour
text: We took the guided tour and it was excellent.  The guide was very passionate and added so much value over just touring yourself.  The building itself has many unique features.  The permanent gallery has many fascinating artifacts.  The rotating gallery was mostly good.  The onsite restaurant is fabulous.

reviews.title: Amazing Islamic Museum
text: We enjoyed how amazing this museum is organized. It has a lot of artificats and Islamic art from historically Muslim civilizations as well as contemporary Muslim communities around the world. You can start by entering the exhibition in the main floor and then you can go upstairs to continue your visit to other exhibitions. It was nice and attractive for adults and kids as well. Sometimes they have events and kids-friendly activites that are attractive for the kids. There is undergound parking where you can park and pay. I really like parking in it specially in cold weather and when you access the building you go through a long ramp, then you can take the elevator or stairs to the main enterance level of the musuem.

reviews.title: wonderful building, housing exquisite collection of Islamic and Ismaili culture.  Knowledgeable guides.
text: One of my favourite spots for an enriching and enjoyable afternoon of learning in cosmopolitan Toronto.
Quiet and serene setting, beautiful gardens,  awe inspiring exhibits.
Always worth a visit. For a special treat, have a meal at the in house restaurant ‘Divan’

reviews.title: AN interesting place to visit
text: Lovely peaceful museum with really nice informative staff. My friend and I also tried the restaurant and had an excellent meal followed by one of the best cappuccino coffees I have had.

reviews.title: Beautiful museum in lovely setting
text: Very beautiful well laid out museum. Gorgeous setting and very helpful staff. Similar to many museums, it studiously avoids topics that could appear to harm one’s image of the culture. There’s no mention of the fact that Islam “spread“ through warfare and conversions. There’s no mention of the fact that there is nothing related to women in the entire permanent exhibit. No discussion of Islam’s problemmatic leadership today. Also Wish there had been more information about the art itself - how was it done, what guidelines were used, etc. Religion is inherently complex and problematic. It’s a great start but I hope they continue to try to step into the complexity rather than sanitize the topic.
